channel.title: How do I copyright my music?
channel.description: Title says it all. Just wanting to get a lot of things out of the way before I get my band underway. :3

item.title: How do I copyright my music?
item.dc:creator: @TabbyKiller TabbyKiller
item.description:
@TabbyKiller wrote:

iTunes is youtubes #1 when it comes to copyrighted music.

Read full topic
item.source: How do I copyright my music?

item.title: How do I copyright my music?
item.dc:creator: @runewings317 runewings317
item.description:
@runewings317 wrote:

[quote=“jme, post:16, topic:438015”][quote author=runewings317 link=topic=540734.msg3961537#msg3961537 date=1333327001]

P.S. it is copyrighted the second you write it. Its proving you wrote it, when you did, that matters.

The old poor mans method was to mail it to themselves and not open it.
[/quote]I saw this and was like “FUCK YES!”. Then I saw that it would rarely hold up in court. Then I was just like “FUCK!”. [size=1pt]truestory[/size]

Sorry if I was misleading, it was something suggested to me by a law professional long ago. I don’t see why it wouldn’t hold up assuming you use your government postal service. It would be dated by the federal government and it would be the earliest known copy of your work. Someone would have a hard time claiming it as their own, when you can prove you had it earlier then they did.[/quote]Oh no, you didn’t But I saw it on this:
[youtube]http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ig5Q9mH7ZXM&feature=plcp&context=C4dc9823VDvjVQa1PpcFNA221sY3sp48QwpY82j9zA_ha_JNXBtVs=[/youtube]

and this is what a commenter said:

This is an URBAN LEGEND. It may work in some other﻿ countries, but in the U.S. it offers you NO copyright-style protection. (For details, go to Snopes [dot] com and search for "Poor Man's Copyright".) Please check out these things before you go telling people to do them!
And the owner of the video posted this:

I read it and I see what you mean, but my method goes beyond "Easily Circumvented" post mark and uses Registered mail which creates a legal document between the sender and the post office. As one of my subscribers suggested, go the extra step and use Registered Certified mail for an extra level of documentation. I did give the disclaimer and I'll say it again. I'm not a﻿ lawyer, I'm just a guy who knows a trick.

But I found this: http://myfreecopyright.com/ <–NVM

So I’m gunna do some research on that and if it doesn’t work, I’ll give what you said a shot for my EP and see if it works.

[quote=“TabbyKiller, post:14, topic:438015”]Can I hear one of your songs?

@topic
Get it up on itunes first
http://msl1.mit.edu/furdlog/docs/baffling_itunes_royalty_calculation.pdf[/quote]I don’t have any yet. I’m just getting 100% ready before I go into this. I’m probably going to try to use TuneCore to upload my music to everywhere I need (yes it hits iTunes). I read this and I’m not quite sure how this is supposed to help me get it copyrighted? What I’m guessing it will do is be copyrighted when I post my songs on it but I’m not sure xD

[quote=“Daginith, post:12, topic:438015”]put a ‘©’ after the song name.[/quote]Lawl. Artem543 told me to do that to RuneWings… Not quite sure why cause it would be a Trademark anyway :L

Read full topic
item.source: How do I copyright my music?

item.title: How do I copyright my music?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

[quote=“runewings317, post:9, topic:438015”][quote author=jme link=topic=540734.msg3961095#msg3961095 date=1333299105]
P.S. it is copyrighted the second you write it. Its proving you wrote it, when you did, that matters.

The old poor mans method was to mail it to themselves and not open it.
[/quote]I saw this and was like “FUCK YES!”. Then I saw that it would rarely hold up in court. Then I was just like “FUCK!”. [size=1pt]truestory[/size][/quote]

Sorry if I was misleading, it was something suggested to me by a law professional long ago. I don’t see why it wouldn’t hold up assuming you use your government postal service. It would be dated by the federal government and it would be the earliest known copy of your work. Someone would have a hard time claiming it as their own, when you can prove you had it earlier then they did.

Read full topic

item.title: How do I copyright my music?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Creative Commons

When we share, everyone wins - Creative Commons

When we share, everyone wins From lawyers and academics to musicians and artists, we’re lighting up a global commons of openness and collaboration, sharing content and community around the world. Get involved

That’ll give you enough protection, essentially your music will be freely distributable, but your band has to have credit. It’s slightly more complicated if you want full protection, so I wont go into that.

Read full topic

item.title: How do I copyright my music?
item.dc:creator: @runewings317 runewings317
item.description:
@runewings317 wrote:

[quote=“Eh Pretty Easy, post:4, topic:438015”]If you’re looking to get money out of your music in the event that it gets popular, here’s what you should check out:

en.wikipedia.org

American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers

The American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers (ASCAP /ˈæskæp/) is an American not-for-profit performance-rights organization (PRO) that protects its members' musical copyrights by monitoring public performances of their music, whether via a broadcast or live performance, and compensating them accordingly. ASCAP collects licensing fees from users of music created by ASCAP members, then distributes them back to its members as royalties. In effect, the arrangement is the product of a...


http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SoundExchange[/quote][quote=“jmood128, post:2, topic:438015”]Add the GPL to it. :)[/quote]Thanks guys

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:3, topic:438015”]http://bit.ly/HxJiyb[/quote]I never ask questions before I google it. =_= When I googled it, it just came up with a bunch of companies…

Read full topic
item.source: How do I copyright my music?

item.title: How do I copyright my music?
item.dc:creator: @Eh_Pretty_Easy Eh Pretty Easy
item.description:
@Eh_Pretty_Easy wrote:

If you’re looking to get money out of your music in the event that it gets popular, here’s what you should check out:

en.wikipedia.org

American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers

The American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers (ASCAP /ˈæskæp/) is an American not-for-profit performance-rights organization (PRO) that protects its members' musical copyrights by monitoring public performances of their music, whether via a broadcast or live performance, and compensating them accordingly. ASCAP collects licensing fees from users of music created by ASCAP members, then distributes them back to its members as royalties. In effect, the arrangement is the product of a...


en.wikipedia.org

SoundExchange

SoundExchange is a non-profit collective rights management organization. It is the sole organization designated by the U.S. Congress to collect and distribute digital performance royalties for sound recordings. It pays featured and non-featured artists and master rights owners for the non-interactive use of sound recordings under the statutory licenses set forth in 17 U.S.C. § 112 and 17 U.S.C. § 114. Overseen by a board of directors composed of artists, artist representatives, and sound recor...

Read full topic
